FacilityName: City of North Bend Wastewater Treatment Plant

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Vacumn regulators, chlorinators, chlorine leak detector, & piping.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
A PROCESS SAFETY ANALYSIS was performed. Currently (2) 1 ton chlorine cylinders are located on site for the purpose of disinfection of wastewater treatment plant effluent. They are attached to one common header.  The 1 ton cylinders contain vacumn regulators that shut down the flow of chlorine gas if the vacumn is broken.  A chlorine leak detector is located next to the chlorine cylinders. The alarm is tied into the treatment plant alarm system.  A low water pressure alarm indicates if the chlorination system is shut down due to lack of water.  A preventative maintenance schedule is set for all associated equipment.
The analysis included physical hazards, equipment used, storage, operation, chemical process,  Alarms, Controls, Instruments, materials of construction & response to an alarm.

A CHLORINE SAFETY PROGRAM that includes training, Warnings & labeling, safety practices, Emergency Repair Kit, and emergency telephone listing.

Material Safety Data Sheets

Worst Case and Alternative Scenarios that includes mapping.

Hazardous Material Response through City Emergency Response Program.

Federal Regulations - Appendix A  40 CFR part 68

City Ordinance - Emergency Management

Miscellaneous Items the city's emergency management plan include, Emergency Operations, Emergency Response, Emergency Response System & the Incident Command.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Regulatory Substance Handled:   Chlorine - for the disinfection of wastewater treatment plant effluent.

Accidental Release Prevention Policy;  We use chlorine for the disinfection of treated municipal effluent.  It is used because it is effective and economical to use.  It is our intention to reduce the chances of an accidental release by reducing the amount of chlorine on site with the consideration of trying to limit the number of times we handled the chlorine.  The city intends to use safety equipment that includes vacuum regulators, chlorine alarms, and physical guarding to help limit the chances of an accident. We also intend to do the following;

1. To operate and maintain equipment in a diligent manner.
2. To train operators on loading & unloading of chlorine cylinders, hook up of cylinders, and a complete 
    understanding of the chlorination system.
3. Maintain a preventative maintenance program.

Worst Case Scenario;

A chlorine  leak in a horizontal 1 ton cylinder.  The tank is 70% full.  The opening of the leak is .36" in diameter, and 1" from the tank bottom.  The release last 12 minutes at a rate of 201 lbs/min.  At 3 ppm the Max. threat zone is 1.2 miles to the end point.

Alternative Release Scenario;

A chlorine gas leak is located in a pipe that is .4 inches in diameter and 8' long. The size of the hole is .13 sq. inches.  Max. release rate equals 6.52 lbs./min. The total amount of gas released is 391 lbs.  Limited duration is 1 hour.  At 3 ppm the Max. threat zone is 354 yards.

5 Year Accident History;  No accidents to report.

Emergency Response;

The City of North Bend Wastewater Treatment Plant Staff does not respond to major chlorine leaks and will evacuate area. The plant staff will react to minor leaks in piping etc. A second person always stands by during exchanging of cylinders.  If a minor leak develops the second person (with SCBA) enters area and shuts off valve on container.  Operator then uses AQUA-AMMONIA to locate leaks.
